Cabin air is provided by electrically driven compressors using no engine-bleed air.{{cite news |url=http://www.designnews.com/document.asp?doc_id=222308 |title=Boeing's 'More Electric' 787 Dreamliner Spurs Engine Evolution: On the 787, Boeing eliminated bleed air and relied heavily on electric starter generators |publisher=[[Design News]] |date= June 4, 2007 |author=Ogando, Joseph, Senior Editor |accessdate=September 9, 2011 }} An advanced cabin air-conditioning system provides better air quality: Ozone is removed from outside air; [[HEPA]] filters remove [[Aerosol|airborne particles]]; and a gaseous filtration system removes odors, irritants, and gaseous contaminants. ==Variants== [[File:Boeing 787 size comparison.svg|thumb|upright=1||Size comparison of the Boeing 787â8 ('''black outline''') with the Boeing [[Boeing 737|737â800]] (green), [[Boeing 767|767â300]] (cyan), and [[Boeing 777|777â300]] (grey).|alt=Diagrams of outlines of three different aircraft imposed over one another.]] Boeing has offered three variants of the 787 from the program launch in 2004. The 787-8 is the first variant produced and is to be followed by the 787-9. ===787-8=== The 787-8 is the base model of the 787 family, with a length of 186 feet (57 m) and a wingspan of 197 feet (60 m) and a range of 7,650 to 8,200 nautical miles (14,200 to 15,200 km), depending on seating configuration. The 787-8 seats 210 passengers in a three-class configuration. The variant was the first of the 787 line to enter service, entering service in 2011. Boeing is targeting the 787-8 to replace the [[Boeing 767-200ER|767-200ER]] and [[767-300ER]], as well as expand into new non-stop markets where larger planes would not be economically viable. Two thirds of 787 orders are for the 787-8. ===787-9=== The 787-9 will be the first variant of the 787 with a "stretched" or lengthened fuselage, seating 250â290 in three classes with a range of 8,000 to 8,500 nautical miles (14,800 to 15,750 km). This variant differs from the 787-8 in several ways, including structural strengthening, a lengthened fuselage, a higher fuel capacity, a higher maximum take-off weight (MTOW), but with the same wingspan as the 787-8. The targeted entry into service (EIS) date, was originally planned for 2010,Wallace, J.[http://www.seattlepi.com/business/221772_air27.html "Aerospace Notebook: New 787 is taking off"]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}. ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'', April 27, 2005. but by October 2011 deliveries were scheduled to begin in early 2014.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/boeing-delays-first-747-8i-and-787-9-deliveries-363941/] Boeing is targeting the 787-9 to compete with both passenger variants of the [[Airbus A330]] and to replace their own [[767-400ER]]. Like the 787-8, it will also open up new non-stop routes, flying more cargo and fewer passengers more efficiently than the 777-200ER or A340-300/500. The firm configuration was finalized on July 1, 2010.{{cite web |title=Boeing clears firm configuration hurdle for 787-9 |publisher=flightglobal |year=2010 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/07/01/343969/boeing-clears-firm-configuration-hurdle-for-787-9.html |accessdate=July 2, 2010}} [[File:Dreamliner render 787-9.JPG|thumb||Artist's impression of the stretched 787-9, designed with greater range and payload capability]] When first launched, the 787-9 had the same fuel capacity as the other two variants. The design differences meant higher weight and resulted in a slightly shorter range than the 787-8. After further consultation with airlines, design changes were incorporated to add a forward tank to increase its fuel capacity, so it has a longer range and a higher MTOW than the other two variants. [[Air New Zealand]] is the launch customer for the 787-9 and the second customer for the 787 after ANA.{{Harvnb|Norris|Wagner|2009|p=50}} ===Other variants=== ====787-3==== This variant was designed to be a 290-seat (two-class) short-range version of the 787 targeted at high-density flights, with a range of 2,500 to 3,050 nautical miles (4,650 to 5,650 km) when fully loaded. Its design used the same basic fuselage as the 787-8. The wing was derived from the 787-8, with blended [[winglets]] replacing raked wingtips. The change decreased the wingspan by roughly {{Convert|25|ft|m}}, allowing the 787-3 to fit into more domestic gates, and in particular in Japan. This model would have been limited in its range by a reduced MTOW of 364,000 lb (165,100 kg).Actual range is based on remaining available weight for fuel after the aircraft empty weight and payload are subtracted from the MTOW. [[File:Dreamliner render 787-3.JPG|thumb|left|An artist's impression of the 787-3, which would have featured a shorter wing with winglets.]] The â3 variant was designed to operate on [[Boeing 757|Boeing 757â300]]/[[Boeing 767|767â200]]-sized regional routes from airports with restricted gate spacing.{{Harvnb|Norris|Wagner|2009|p=38}} Boeing projected that the future of aviation between very large, but close cities of five million or more people may stabilize around the capacity level of the 787-3.{{cite web |url=http://boeingblogs.com/randy/archives/2005/05/kangaroo_hop.html |title=Kangaroo hop |work=Randy's Journal |publisher=The Boeing Company |date= May 20, 2005 |author=Baseler, Randy |accessdate=July 10, 2007 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/atr/public/comments/209455.htm |title= Congestion And Delay Reduction At Chicago O'Hare International Airport: Docket No. FAA-2005-20704 |work=Comments of The United States Department of Justice |publisher=Before The Federal Aviation Administration Department of Transportation |date= May 24, 2005 |author=Pate, R. Hewitt (Assistant Attorney General, Antitrust Division); McDonald, Bruce (Deputy Assistant Attorney General, Antitrust Division) and Gillespie, William H. (Economist) |accessdate=September 2, 2011 }} Forty-three 787-3s were ordered by the two Japanese airlines, but production problems on the base 787-8 model led Boeing to postpone the introduction of the 787-3 in April 2008, following the 787-9 but without a firm delivery date. By December 2009, all 787-3 orders had been converted to the 787-8.{{cite web|url=http://active.boeing.com/commercial/orders/index.cfm?content=userdefinedselection.cfm&pageid=m15527|title=Orders and Deliveries search page|publisher=Boeing|date=July 21, 2010}} At the time, it was likely the 787-3 variant would be shelved entirely following the lack of interest by potential customers caused by its being designed specifically for the Japanese market.{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2010963351_boeingbloom03.html |title=Boeing will likely scrap 787-3 |work=The Seattle Times |date=February 2, 2010 |accessdate=February 7, 2010}} On December 13, 2010, Boeing did cancel the 787-3, since it was no longer financially viable after its orders were canceled.{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/boeingaerospace/2013672244_boeingprices14.html |title=Boeing raises aircraft prices 5.2%, cancels short-haul 787 |publisher=Seattle Times |date=December 13, 2010 |first=Susanna |last=Ray}} ====787-10==== Boeing has stated that it is likely to develop another version, the longer 787-10, with [[seating capacity]] between 290 and 310.{{Cite news |last=Wallace |first=James |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/default/article/Everett-work-force-for-787-pegged-at-1-000-1190602.php |title=Everett work force for 787 pegged at 1,000 |publisher=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=December 22, 2005 |accessdate=September 2, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://atwonline.com/aircraftenginescomponents/news/boeing-looks-larger-dreamliner-meet-emirates-ba-requirements-0309 |title=Boeing looks at larger Dreamliner to meet Emirates, BA requirements |author=Thomas, G. |date=September 26, 2005 |work=[[Air Transport World]] |accessdate=September 3, 2011}} This proposed model is intended to compete with the planned Airbus [[Airbus A350|A350-900]].{{cite news |url=http://atwonline.com/aircraftenginescomponents/news/boeing-bullish-787-10-dreamliner-production-0309 |title=Boeing bullish on 787-10, Dreamliner production |author=Thomas, G. |date=December 23, 2005 |work=[[Air Transport World]] |publisher=ATW Media Group |accessdate=September 2, 2011}} The 787-10 would supersede the [[Boeing 777|777-200ER]] in Boeing's current catalog and could also compete against the [[Airbus A330|Airbus A330-300]] and [[Airbus A340|A340-300/500]]. Boeing was having discussions with potential customers about the 787-10 in 2006 and 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/randy/archives/2006/02/dash_10.html |title=Dash 10 |work=Boeing Blog |author=Baseler, Randy |date= February 8, 2006 |accessdate= November 17, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/b575de2a-2d75-11dc-939b-0000779fd2ac,dwp_uuid=e8477cc4-c820-11db-b0dc-000b5df10621.html |title=Customers guard Boeing 787 delivery slots |work=Financial Times |date= July 8, 2007 |author=Cameron, Doug and Kevin Done |accessdate=July 8, 2007}}{{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2007/q2/070619c_nr.html |title=Boeing Highlights Progress on First 787, Subsequent Airplanes |work=Boeing Press Release |author=Leach, Yvonne and Gunter, Lori |date= June 19, 2007 |accessdate=June 23, 2007}} In March 2006 Mike Bair, the head of the 787 program at the time, stated that "It's not a matter of if, but when we are going to do it ... The 787-10 will be a stretched version of the 787-9 and sacrifice some range to add extra seat and cargo capacity.""{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB114349310320609340.html |title=Boeing to Build Stretch 787 Jet |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=March 27, 2006 |first=J. Lynn |last=Lunsford}} Boeing has not yet officially launched the -10, but it remains under consideration as of 2011.{{cite news |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story.jsp?id=news/aw062308p3.xml&headline=Boeing%20Reconsiders%20Plan%20for%20787-10&channel=awst |title=Boeing Reconsiders Plan for 787-10 |author=Wall, Robert |publisher=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] |date=June 20, 2008 |accessdate=June 14, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://atwonline.com/aircraft-engines-components/news/bernstein-boeing-moving-closer-787-10-0601 |title=Bernstein: Boeing moving closer to a 787-10 |publisher= ATW online |author=Thomas, Geoffrey |date= June 2, 2011 |accessdate=November 17, 2011}} ====Further proposals==== Although no date has been set, Boeing expects to build a 787 freighter version, possibly in 10 to 15 years.Ng, J. [http://www.marketwatch.com/story/boeing-executive-says-no-freighter-version-of-787-likely-for-10-years Boeing executive says no freighter version of 787 is likely for 10 years], Marketwatch from Dow Jones. Retrieved January 2, 2008. Boeing is reported to be also considering a 787 variant as a candidate to replace the 747-based [[Boeing VC-25|VC-25]] as [[Air Force One]].{{Cite news|last=Butler|first=Amy|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/AF1-012809.xml|title=Boeing Only Contender for New Air Force One|publisher=AviationWeek.com|accessdate=June 14, 2011}} ==Orders and deliveries== {{Main|List of Boeing 787 orders and deliveries}} The 787 was first officially delivered to launch customer [[All Nippon Airways]] in September 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightstory.net/20110826/boeing-787-dreamliner-date-for-first-delivery |title= Boeing 787 Dreamliner â Date for First Delivery |author=Michael |publisher=Flight Story |date= August 26, 2011 |accessdate=August 26, 2011}} [[ILFC]] (International Lease Finance Corporation) is its largest customer with orders totaling 74 Boeing 787s, comprising 33 -8s and 41 -9s.{{cite web|url=http://active.boeing.com/commercial/orders/displaystandardreport.cfm?cboCurrentModel=787&optReportType=AllModels&cboAllModel=787&ViewReportF=View+Report |title= 787 Model Orders and Deliveries summary |publisher=Boeing |date= June 2011 |accessdate=July 25, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/01/30/321910/boeing-resumes-787-production.html |title=Boeing resumes 787 production |work=Flight International |date= January 30, 2009 |accessdate=September 2, 2011}}
